column7: ADC_ Business Segment. Details
column8: The BAS_Business_Segment (Table 4) and the BAS_Business_Segment_Hierarchy (Table 6) have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units, e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project. Instructions on how to implement the business segment structures (4.4.2 and 4.4.3) are detailed in Annex A.The fields within the BAS_Business_Segment (Table 4) are used to capture the individual organizational unit represented by each box on an organizational diagram.

column7: ADC_ Business Segment. ID
column8: The code of each business segment.
column9: XBRL GL tracks hierarchy ID, hierarchy description, and hierarchy type, so it can track code "NA," description "N. America," and type "global area" using gl-cor:accountSubID, gl-cor:accountSubDescription, and gl-cor:accountSubType, respectively. Interrelations and hierarchies are captured by gl-cor:parentSubAccountType (What is the hierarchy type this unit rolls up to?).

column7: ADC_ Business Segment. Business Segment. Name
column8: The name of the business segment.
column9: See above; an unlimited number of units and structures are permitted.

column7: ADC_ Business Segment. Segment Reference Level. Code
column8: The relative level of the segment with being the consolidated level and numbers increasing through lower levels of the organizational chart.
column9: The relationships between higher-level hierarchies are captured once per Business Segment.

column7: ADC_ Business Segment. Organization Type. Name
column8: Indicates the name of the organization type, for example, "Department" and "Cost Center".

column7: ADC_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Details
column8: The fields in the BAS_Business_Segment_Hierarchy (Table 6) are used to capture the relationships between the individual organization units. The table assumes a one_to_one relationship and captures the data necessary to consolidate transactions occurring for child level organizational units into higher level organizational structures (for example, business unit to division).  Instructions on how to implement the business segment structures (see 4.4.2 and 4.4.3) are detailed in Annex A.

column7: ADC_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Parent. ADC_ Business Segment
column8: The code of the parent business segment. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.

column7: ADC_ Business Segment Hierarchy. Child. ADC_ Business Segment
column8: The code of the child business segment. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Details
column8: The personnel information of the employee in an independent accounting unit is contained in Table 8.

column7: ADC_ Employee. ID
column8: The unique identifier for an employee. Typically auto-generated by the system.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Code
column8: The code of the employee. Each employee has only one code. If someone does part-time jobs in multiple departments, there will be more than one record with different Employee_ID in this table. And the part-time status will be reflected in Employee_Type_Code.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Name
column8: The name of the employee.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Inactive Flag. Indicator
column8: Indicate whether one employee is active or inactive. One employee may become inactive due to some reasons such as sabbatical.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Type Code
column8: The code of the employee types. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent an on-the-job employee, 005 to represent a retired employee, 006 to represent a deceased employee, and 007 to represent a part-time employee.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Type Name
column8: The name of the employee type. EXAMPLE Employed, retired, probation and part-time.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Department. ADC_ Business Segment
column8: The code of department rosters. EXAMPLE The IT department is designated as code 0018. Shall match the Business_Segment_Code in the BAS_Business_Segment table.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Job Title. Name
column8: The title of the person in an accounting unit. EXAMPLE Accounting manager.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Academic Degree
column8: The highest academic degree acquired. EXAMPLE Doctor, Master.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Employment Date
column8: The employment date of the employee.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Termination Date
column8: The termination date of the employee from which the labor contract was no longer valid, or the employee no longer works in this department.

column7: ADC_ Employee. Associated. ADC_ User
column8: The system user ID associated with the employee. hall match the User_ID in the BAS_User table.

column7: ADC_ User. Status Modified Date

column7: ADC_ User. User Job Title. Name

column7: ADC_ User. User Role Responsibility

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Details
column8: The information about GL accounts, including name, description, type and hierarchy is contained in Table 20. When it is cross-referred by other table(s), consistency shall apply. For example, in this table, the value of GL_Account_Number is 101, the value of GL_Account_Name is cash, and the value of Balance_Debit_Or_Credit is D, if the value of GL_Account_Number in GL_Tial_Balance table is 101, then the Amount corresponding with cash account (101) must be debit.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. ID
column8: The GL account number.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. GL Account. Name
column8: The name of the GL account.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Description
column8: The label or description associated with the GL_Account_Number.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Caption
column8: The financial statement caption represents a related group of accounts. EXAMPLE Cash and cash equivalents, accounts payable and cost of sales. The caption can be at the trial balance level.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Account Type. Code
column8: The type of account. EXAMPLE Assets, liabilities, equity, revenues and expenses.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Accountount Subtype. Code
column8: The subtype of the account. EXAMPLE Current assets are the subtype of assets.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Account Hierarchy. Numeric
column8: The corresponding level for account number in the account hierarchy. EXAMPLE Using 1 to represent assets, and 2 to represent the account subtype current assets.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. GL Account Number. ADC_ Chart Of Accounts
column8: The number of the parent account in an account hierarchy. This is provided to allow more than the predefined levels of the hierarchy in the BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table. When Parent_GL_Account_Number is the highest level, its value can be set to the default value; for example, set to NULL. Shall match the GL_Account_Number in BAS_Chart_Of_Accounts table.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Debit Or Credit. indicator
column8: This field is used to indicate whether the natural balance of the account is a debit or credit balance by indicating "D" or "C", where assets and expenses have a natural balance of debit, and liabilities, equity and revenues have a natural balance of credit.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. Active Flag. Indicator
column8: This indicates whether the GL account is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.

column7: ADC_ Chart Of Accounts. X. ADC_ Business Segment
column8: A reserved field that shall be used for business segments/structures. The 'X' signifies an organizational level. Each number used to replace the 'X' is associated with a unique reference level. For example, division, department, business unit, purchasing organization, project or legal entity.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. Details
column8: The information related to accounting period including the corresponding fiscal year, the beginning and ending date is contained in Table 22. The table captures the time range within a specific reporting period and year, in which business transactions and entries are accumulated into financial statements and other reports.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. ID
column8: The unique identifier for the accounting period.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. Fiscal Year. Code
column8: The fiscal year in which the calendar date occurs. The year shall be shown in four digits as "YYYY", which is part of the extended format and the "YYYYMM-DD" in ISO 8601-1.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. Period. Code
column8: The accounting period in which the calendar date occurs. EXAMPLE W1_W53 for weekly periods, M1_M12 for monthly periods, Q1_Q4 for quarterly periods, and from any beginning date to any ending date.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. Beginning. Date
column8: The calendar beginning date of the current accounting period.

column7: ADC_ Fiscal Period. Ending. Date
column8: The calendar ending date of the current accounting period.

column7: ADC_ Journal Entry Type. ID

column7: ADC_ Bill Type. Details
column8: The information of bill type, for example, bank draft, commercial draft, promissory note and check are contained, is contained in Table 26. Bills are frequently used in the business cycle of sales and purchase, as evidence of debt, payment and/or settlement instrument.

column7: ADC_ Bill Type. ID
column8: The code of the bill type. EXAMPLE Using 004 to represent bank draft, 005 to represent promissory note, and 006 to represent check.

column8: The information on methods used to settle transactions is contained in Table 28. Businesses can adopt various methods to settle transactions and transfer money, especially in sales and purchase activities. Typical settlement methods include: cash settlements, issuing bills, using credit cards, bank remittances and bank collections.

column7: ADC_ Settlement Method. ID
column8: The code of the settlement method. Various methods can be used to settle transactions and transfer money; for example, 001 for cash, 002 for bills, 003 for credit card, 004 for remittance, and 005 for bank collection.

column7: ADC_ Settlement Method. Settlement Method. Name
column8: The name of the settlement method. EXAMPLE Cash settlement, issuing bills, credit card, bank remittance and bank collection.

column7: ADC_ Settlement Method. Active Flag. Indicator
column8: This indicates whether the settlement method is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.

column7: ADC_ Currency. Details
column8: The information of the currency is contained in Table 30.

column7: ADC_ Currency. ID
column8: The code of the currency (ISO 4217).

column7: ADC_ Currency. Currency. Name
column8: The name of the currency in the accounting and/or ERP system.

column7: ADC_ Currency. Minor Unit. Numeric
column8: The unit of recorded value which is a division of the respective unit of currency. Minor unit shows the decimal relationship between such unit and the currency itself (ISO 4217). Number 0 means that there is no minor unit for that currency, whereas number 1, 2, 3, etc. signify a ratio of 10:1, 100:1, 1 000:1, etc. respectively. EXAMPLE The US cent is a one hundredth part of the US dollar; the GB penny is a one hundredth part of the pound sterling. The minor unit number for both is 2.

column7: ADC_ Currency. Active Flag. Indicator
column8: This indicates whether Currency_Code is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.

column7: ADC_ Measurement Unit. ID

column7: ADC_ Measurement Unit. UOM. Name

column7: ADC_ Measurement Unit. Active Flag. Indicator
column8: This indicates whether the UOM_Code is active or inactive. EXAMPLE 1 is active and 0 is inactive.
